author: Joel Moreno, KOMO News Reporter
title: chevron-right
text: SEATTLE — The shootings, assaults, sex trafficking and other crimes that occur along Seattle’s Aurora Avenue North will be the focus of a community conversation on Thursday night, hosted by Seattle City Councilmember Cathy Moore and other local leaders. While the latest data shows overall crime is down along the corridor, police said some categories continue to show troubling increases. Those areas include shots fired, robberies, auto theft and violent crime. ALSO SEE | [Man shot and killed outside north Seattle gas station](https://komonews.com/news/local/seattle-homicide-man-shot-killed-n-northgate-way-aurora-ave-n-arco-gas-station-ampm-spd-cpr-crime-gun-violence) Moore has been tracking the concerns raised during meetings of the North Precinct Advisory Council. Statistics presented during those meetings show that overall crime in Seattle’s North Precinct is down 12%. However, violent crime has increased 17%, shots fired are up 35% and auto theft has increased 20% compared to the same time period in 2023. ALSO SEE | [Teens plead not guilty in deliberate hit-and-run attacks along Aurora Avenue](https://komonews.com/news-brief-newsletter/teens-charged-hit-and-run-vehicular-assaults-king-county-superior-court-judge-veronica-galvan-arraignment-13-15-year-old-stolen-car-court-documents-seattle-aurora-avenue-graphic-injuries) The most recent crime trends available show there have been 31 shots fired incidents in the North Precinct so far this year, leading to one person being killed and another 10 people wounded. A flashpoint area is around Aurora and North 105th Street, according to police. FROM OCTOBER | ['No sleep for Aurora': North Seattle residents blame drugs, prostitution on rising crime, shootings in neighborhoods](https://komonews.com/news/local/no-sleep-for-aurora-north-seattle-residents-blame-drugs-prostitution-on-rising-crime-and-shootings-in-their-neighborhoods-seattle-police-deparment-wild-west-danger-protection-community-deterrent-patrol) Along with Moore, Seattle police Chief Adrian Diaz, Community Assisted Response and Engagement Chief Amy Smith, Seattle police Captain Lori Aagard, staff from the Seattle Department of Transportation, as well as members of the Aurora Avenue community will be taking part in the discussion. The District 5 public safety forum begins at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at the Bitterlake Community Center, located at North 130th Street and Linden Avenue North.
